Finish is lightly bitter and nicely dry with a bit of hop resin.   This stuff is pretty good but it doesn’t hold a candle to pliny.

bottle bought in Colorado!  golden/copper pour with thin head.  nice fresh wet hops and big citrus in aroma.  beautiful hoppy, sweet malts.  great balance.  a bitterness that works down to the belly.  solid.

bottle shared by JMFG: pours a golden honey with a small white head. aroma is a great sweet hops and nice malt to go along with it. the hops seem so fresh. flavour is a good wet hop bitter earthy a nice malt but does not balance the hops wich is ok .

Bottle via Dunk, thanks Steve!   That lasted in the fridge less than 24hrs.   Pours golden/copper color with a medium sized off-white head.   Aroma is grapefruit, pine, caramel, floral.   Flavor is huge blast of pine, citrus notes, that settle into caramel and grapefruit.   Palate is medium+, medium carbonation, finished bitter.   Resiny finish, sticky on the lips.   Surprised its only 70IBU, ranks up with the best IPA’s!!

@Richmond/Williamsburg Gathering-16.9 oz bottle-pours a thin white head and yellow color.  Aroma is pine/citrus.  Taste is pine/pungent/earthy/citrus, hint of medium malt.  Semi dry.  Thanks Chris for sharing.

(50cl bottle, thanks kmweaver) Medium off-white head that leaves nice lacing atop hazy apple juice body.  Aroma is medium sweet, pine, some grapefruit, mango.  Taste is medium sweet, pine/grapefruit, some spicy, peach.  Resiny medium body.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2008 Pours amber brown with thin white head. Aroma is hops, hops and hops with subtle roastiness and pine. Flavor begins roasty and citrusy and finishes with nice hops in the throat and sinus. Medium body with very nice mouth feel. Very good IPA.

This is great, I could smell the hops 3 feet from my face.  Aroma is of beautiful hops with the pine and citrus coming through with them.  Appearance is gorgeous, slightly pale golden at the bottom and darkens to a copper gold at the top with a thick white head.  Flavor, hops with grapefruit and pine along for the ride.  Palate is perfect bitterness, smooth in the start.  First Russian River to rate (had Younger when I was drunk so can’t rate that), and definitely didn’t disappoint!!  Made props to golubj.  Thanks a bunch.
Bottle.  Pours golden/orange.  Nice, piney hop aroma.  Great citrus hop taste.  Could drink this all day.  Light and not overwhelming with hops.  Very good IPA.

Thanks to mwompus on BA for this one.  The bottle is only 16 days old so its super fresh.  Thanks again.  Pours a vibrant orange with a lasting white head that leaves plenty of lace on the glass. Tons of resinous, piney hop smell with some grapefruit and spicy/earthy hop tones as well.  Pine definitely dominates this great nose.  Tons of pine and smooth taste that just slides over the palate. So smooth, refreshing, and easy to drink that I would make this an everyday beer if I could.  A great single IPA.

Bottle courtesy of thecheeseman. Pours orange with off white head. Big pine, grass and grapefruit aroms. Similar flavors with some sweet maltiness lingering around. Medium body with average carbonation and a sticky mouthfeel. A very good IPA.

Courtesy of kmweaver. Hazy pale with a small white head. Massive grapefruit and tangerine nose with an unfortunate crystal malt note underneath. The flavor is lightly sweet, with ice tea, grapefruit, some pine, tangerine and a bit of cattiness. Medium body is round with moderate carbonation.

Bottle thanks to AgentSteve.  Big white head atop this dark golden gem.  Big pine and citurs nose.  Flavor is huge on hops with a mild backing of malt.  Really need to chew through these hops, but I didn’t want it to end.

16.9 oz bottle. Bottled on 7-22-08. Poured a nice dark gold, white head. Smells wonderful, huge pine notes, a little citrus as well, glorious. Great hoppiness all over the place, it’s a tongue wagger. Great beer.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Oh my goodness. Bitter. Hoppy. Bit of toasty taste to it. Everything reputation led me to believe it would be. I envy those SF beer drinkers who can probably get this on tap all the time. What aroma. What taste.  I split the bottle with my wife.

Bottle, bottled six days prior to purchase from Toronado SF.  Amber color, thin even white layer of foam.  Peppery hop aroma with some citric background.  Very tasty - darkly citric hop character plays on the palate right away,followed by some malts.  The hop finish lingers nicely.  Very nice.

slightly hazed bronze with a very long lasting off white head that may slowy shrink but certainly leaves its mark on the glass.  sweet and herbal hop nose.  flavors here are on the spicey side of hoppy and suprisingly maybe a touch too balanced...or not...christmas pine flavors with bitterness only in the finish but such bitterness is rather grassy/earthy and the after taste is all bitter bite...but there’s no bite until then.  other than christmas pine and the bite at the end, there isnt much to talk about...overall its clean with a more spicey hop character than is normal round these parts but other than that, its a bit one dimensional and uninspiring.

500mL. Bottled on 070908. Excellent balance of citrus, pine and a rustic woodsiness on the nose. Cedar. Mint. Dried cannabis. A touch of dried grass and dirt. Solid chewy, but not fat, malt backbone. Pours a glowing, bright clear copper with a sticky white  head. Toasted malt and resiny hops intermingle quite nicely on the tongue. Minty, earthy, grassy. Plenty hoppy for sure. More cedar, grapefruit rind. Mild peachy and apricot notes. Herbal, floral and piny. Lively, spritzy and firm on the tongue. Oily hops linger but the malt comes in to play as well. The finish is gloriously hoppy and earthy that lasts forever. Thanks Brian!

Small tan head, good retention with a nice stringy lace left behind. Hazy gold with a light copper hue. Big ol hop nose, pine, earth, grass and grapefruit with soft malt backing. Body is med/full, chewy, resiny and coating on the palate. Strong hop flavors, grapefruit, pine and sosme cedar notes. Faint maltiness, fairly dry, lightly toasty from what i can find under the serious hop blanket. Dry, citrusy biggass hop finish, lingering lovingly, bite. A manly IPA for sure. Props to cloudskipper for the bottle!

Clear golden yellow pour with a thin white head.  Peachy floral aroma with lots of citrus.  Very good - similar to Pliny the Elder but not quite intense.  Good fruity grapefruit and peach flavor.  Very mild (I drank the Pliny right before this!).  Bitter hop finish.  Malty and balanced.  Very good IPA.
Slitghtly cloudy golden color pour with hop, and fruity aroma and flavors.  Very sharp finish.

50 cl bottle courtesy of FlacoAlto - Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a one and a half finger thick off white head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is big floral, fruity, and pine hops.  Flavor is much of the same with some malt sweetness in there.  Body and mouthfeel is a little lighter than I expected.  Has an herbal hop finish.  No unpleasant or lingering aftertaste.  A very nice IPA.  Thanks Sebastian.

Bottle from Beerguy101. I had this on tap at Toronado San Diego, but I was socializing and not rating. Pours a very nice amber orange with a slight haze, with a huge foamy and retentive off white head. Body is on the lighter side of medium, with a light but not watery texture. Fresh hop aroma of exotic fruit. Hops dominate the flavor, starting sweet grapefruit and moving to grass and pine. Finish is semi dry, very bitter, with lots of lingering grapefruit rind. A nice hophead session beer.

Bottle from trade with golubj.  Thanks Jon!  Pours a hazy orangish amber color with a nice white head. Aroma of hops, pine needles and grapefruit. Taste is hoppy with a touch of citrus and a very small hint of malt. Finish is bitter and very dry. Not quite as balanced as the Elder.
Bottle pours a clear golden color with a medium well lacing tan head. Very crisp citrus and hop aromas. Great mix of hops provides a balanced taste of citrus and hops.Very rrisp and clean.

On draft at O’Brien’s. Appearance is a clear amber hue, thin white layer of dense head, big thick lacing all over the glass. Smell is huge hops --grapefruit, pine resin, grass, lemon zest--, sweet bread malt tones linger in the background. Taste is moderate-full hop flavors, sweet grapefruit and citrus balance out the more bitter pine resin, hints of bread and grain malts are barely perceptible, finishes dry and bitter. Palate is full-bodied, thick and oily texture, moderate carbonation. Overall great flavor and body for a single IPA at 6%, solid throughout, no glaring shortcomings for this style, definitely a favorite and repeat performer, this ranks on my short list of top single IPAs

Richmond Summer Gathering. 500ml bottle - not sure who brought this one. Clear golen orange with a white head. AMAZING nose - a hop festival! Mild malts barely standing behind a wall of hop scents - grassy, orange citrus, herbal... just WOW. Dry floral flavors, grassy with light caramel. Somehow, the flavor never delivers on the promises of the fantastic nose. Still, a really good IPA.

~Pours a light golden color with lasting white head. Good lacing.
~Nice grapefruit hop aroma with slight malty sweetness.
~Good citrusy flavor, mild malts.
~Medium sticky feel, bitter finish.
~A nice west coast IPA. Nothing spectacular though.

Bottle from Joey.  500ml.  Bottled 2 weeks before I drank it, cant get much fresher.  After drinking the Pliny I had a while ago, I was very excited to get to try this one.  Orange colored pour with no head.  Smell is a giant amount of hops.  Smells like a fresh hop, grassy, some orange, awesome.  This is how a beer should smell.  Taste is bitter, like eating a hop cone, very refreshing.  Something that will not find the back of my celler, this one needs to be drank immediately.  Really good stuff, typical of RR.

22oz bottle. Nose is lightly citric with resiny hops. Bit Floral as well. Pours a clear orange. Flavor is very hoppy but not at all soapy or astringent. Very evenly balanced. Good mouthfeel reveals a decent malt background. Very well crafted. Great IPA

500mL bottle, courtesy of cloudskipper.  Thanks, Chris!  Pours a bright, clear golden-orange color; fluffy white head with solid retention and fine-bubbled lacing.  Just tons of dense, bitter, generous hoppiness in the aroma: citrus, pine, and herbal; hoppy as all hell, without astringency; a really nice nose.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: lots of soft, chewy hop bitterness throughout: dense herbal, grassy, and citrus hop notes, and without any of the typically necessary malt underpinnings to keep things drinkable; this is just a gorgeous, unabashed, refined display of hoppy goodness; very drinkable, minimal astringency, and just a very generous hop profile throughout; an archetype of bitterness-driven IPAs.  Lengthy finish: mineral, herbal, and grassy hops; lasting bitterness; a touch of toasty malts come through at the far shore.

On tap At O’Brien’s in San Diego on 08/01/2008 on the RBSG Friday Pub Crawl. Clear golden amber bofy with a small white head. Citrus floral and grassy hop aroma. Dry grassy, floral and light citrus hop flavor with a firm bitterness in the finish. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

Huge thanks to swnicholson for the chance!
Poured from the bottle (bottled 7/9/08) to a tulip. Nice hazy orange with a sticky white head. Good retention. Some floral aromas along with some orange and grapefruit. 
Great hop bite right up front. Mellows with a wonderful fruity hop lingering bitterness. Ths one is chewy and delicious. It has that extra je ne sais quois that most ipas lack. Might be the sticky, oily, fruity hop flavor that does not just make it a hip bomb, but also gives it some balance. It is not just bitter, but full of flavor as well. Wonderful beer.

Very pungent and spicy initial hop aroma blows off to a milder level that offers more citrus within the first thirty seconds.  Hazy deep golden body is topped by a decent, if large bubbled white head that lasts well.  Strong bitterness lacks a sufficient malt backbone to adequately support it.  Plenty of citrus, grassy and pine-like hop flavours but malt sweetness is almost not there.  Very dry medium body with decent and lasting carbonation.  Sampled on tap at Beachwood Bbq with JohnC

A golden color with a small soapy head. The aroma is hoppy with some lemons and perfume. The flavor is somewhat bitter with some lemons, oranges, and a hint of pine. The aftertaste is bitter as well. The palate is a bit thin but overall this is a nice IPA if not a complex one.

Dark golden in color almost copper with a nice thin lacy head.  Nice aromas of hops citrus (lemon), and pine.  taste is some bitterness, fruits, hops, and goodness.  Nice blance and a good beer.  Really nice aromas going on.

Bottled 07/09/08.  A misty apricot orange and a thin whitecap.  Resinous and wet cannabis and lychee rind aroma; grassy, bitter and herbal; a gorgeously damp sagebrush and citrus rind hoppiness with a sparse dusting of pepper.  Perfect hop character, and a calm sweetness of almond and cotton candy and sugar cookies.  Its pretty and pristine.An abrasive pinecone bitterness intimates a sharp edge in the immediate flavor; it hits with a violent crunch, like a sudden waft of wet pine smoke in the throat.  Softly, a smooth fruitiness of apricots, pears, and tangerines lends a perfectly complimentary brightness and sweetness, and it stays almost totally settled on this sunny orchard sensation; the bitterness is pure pine and hemp, lingering on grapefruit only for a moment, before those glowing sweet citrus and stone fruit oils wash over.  Freshest hops.  As it warms, some wildflower honey and doughy malt presents, calmly, and cleanly; its inarguably impressive how well-drawn the hop and malt characters are individually, and how beautifully they bleed into each other as the beer unfolds.Soft, medium palate, lightly sticky with resins and floral honey.  Gentle carbonation.  Finish is green herbal bitterness, of cannabis, pine, and sage, just lightly vegetal.  While its perfectly refreshing and its hop presence is so attractive and forceful, it gets just lightly astringent with raw greenness and celery crunch at the very end, and so it must remain as a world-class, if not highest peak, example.  Thanks Ty!

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2008 Bottled July 22, 2008; Sampled August 7, 2008 Pours into my New Belgium Globe glass with a nice pungent scent and a two-finger thick, pale tan colored head that has some stickiness to it. The beer is a hazy amber hue that shows a more copper hue when held up to the light. Sticky grapefruit notes mix with sweet lychee notes, which are offset in the finish by a sticky herbal note that takes on overtones of hemp oil, peppery sage and just plain, green, hop-stink. Vivaciously hoppy, this has the fruit character that I like in a good IPA as well as the balancing, dank hoppiness that is needed for balance. Quite a nice example of a beer that captures the essence of concentrated hop nectar. No real malt aromatics are noticeable, if you really dig for them there is just a wisp of toasty, pale malt, but only just. Sharply bitter up front, then the mouth coats the palate and helps to carry the hop flavor, but the bitterness kicks back in towards the finish and lingers on in the mouth with an herbal edge to it. After my first sip I feel like I was just chewing on some fresh hops. Citrus & hop-fruit flavors of grapefruit, bergamot oil, lychee and bright tangelo make a significant showing, but are ultimately engulfed by the palate coating, herbal bitterness that is what is left lingering on in the palate after each sip has passed down my throat. Impressively quaffable, this has some heft to it with enough body to just carry the hops, but remains light enough to be drinkable like a good IPA should. This is definitely a beer for the hopheads out there. It definitely doesn’t pull any punches and is aggressively hoppy. If in the mood for an aggressive hop experience this definitely fits the bill. It doesn’t get overly harsh and it is just so dang quaffable. This is much more aromatic and hop flavorful than the draught sample I had previously. Sampled at Lucky Baldwin’s IPA festival, June 2007 Pours with a very fluffy, initially three-finger thick, pale, tan colored head that sits atop an orangish, lightly hazy, copper colored brew. The aroma is sharply citrus-like in character, but a backdrop of green, hop aromatics reminiscent of menthol, pine and an herbal note reminiscent of green basil and hemp. The beer tastes quite dry and this really accentuates the biting hop notes. The beer is quite smooth, or without much carbonation as the pour from the tap seems to have knocked out most of the carbonation. Flavors of orange peel and tart grapefruit are joined by herbaceous, green, dank, hop flavors; the last of these really linger on in the finish along with a not-overwhelming, but persistent bitterness and a green astringency. As the beer warms a bit I begin to pick up some menthol-like notes as well. While this is quite hoppy (both the citrus side and the herbal side of the hop), it still manages to be quite smooth and drinkable. The appearance of this beer is perfect (albeit this is somewhat arbitrary) as I really can’t ask for more; it has a nice light haze that let you know copious amounts of hops were used here).

Wafting tangerines in the aroma.  Slightly hazy medium gold in color.  Little head.  Medium bodied, certainly better as it warmed.  Very specific hoppiness, live and direct with the simcoes and amarillos.  Incredibly juicy and resinous with a lingering  hoppiness.  Quite a nice IPA.
Bottle from Monument Liqours in Concord, CA. Smelled of citurs hops. If you like hops this is the beer for you. Citurs hops dominated the flavor and very even feel on the palate. Good brew!!

Bottle shared by cdumler at the 2008 Richmond Summer Gathering in Williamsburg. Thanks Chris! Pours an amber color with a smallish head. Taste and aroma are both full of big citrus and earthy hops. Bitter and full bodied.

On tap at O’Brians RBSG. Pine and grapefruit nose, floral but still sharp. Pours gold with a white head. Sharp hop flavor, very dry and crisp which amplified the sharpness. Good IPA, but a palate scraper from the bitterness.

From tap at Pizza Port in San Clemente. Pours cloudy orange with a lacing white head. Fruity hops aroma, light peachy quite inviting. Solid grapefruit and mild peach hoppy flavour. Dry and slight bitter spiced finish. Smooth and greatly balanced.

Thanks to DTM for the bottle from Monument in Concord, CA.  This brew had a nice hoppy hit on the palate (pure citrus, mainly grapefruit).  It’s tough to give it perfect marks because the bitterness lingered, although controlled, which could have been intentional.  It lacked any maltiness, but I wasn’t expecting much in that department.

Bottle thanks to Eric. Pours a clear golden body with a thin white head. The aroma is awesome; citrus hops and I mean tons of hop goodness. The taste was more mellow; a smooth sweet hop flavor, some grapefruit and sweet malts. Easygoing and very tasty.

500ml bottle, Thanks to cdumelr at Richmond Summer Gathering @ Williamsburg. Pours clear golden in color with white head. Aroma of citrus hops and hops. Taste is dry and citrus hops with dry and bitter finish.

Bottle at RBSG grand tasting. Thanks to whoever brought this.Pours a cloudy yellow with an ample white head. The aroma was green with chlorophyll hops and a bit of pine. The flavor was biter hops forward with pine and tangy grapefruit. The mouthfeel is full and malty. The finish is long with lingering hops. Overall: This is a superbly well crafted IPA, biter but not harshly so. Another winner.

(From 8-3-08 sampling, thanks to who shared with everyone!) Transparent orange yellow in color, white ring around the glass for a head, hops and earth on the nose.  His the mouth with a high-light body, hops come in the middle and last to the finish, a small tangy note on the finish.  Pleasureable.

Bottle. Pours hazy gold with a thin and lacy white head. Medium-to-light body and moderate carbonation. Grapefruit, floral and resin aroma. Sweet taste of caramel and oranges. Crisp finish. Nice stuff.

Pours a slightly hazy bright golden amber with a big fluffy white head that hangs around for quite a while leaving big clumps of lacing.  The smell is huge on floral and citrus hops - grapefruit and pine just jump out of the bottle when it’s opened.  The taste is hops galore with grapefruit stinging the tongue with bitterness up front and pine resins lingering on the palate at the finish.  There is a hint of the bready hop background, but the hops steal the show here.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, creamy and sticky with hop oils.  This is one of the best IPAs I have tasted and especially enjoyable for hopheads like me.

Aroma is orangy as fuck.  All of the good IPAs seem to have the same hop profile.  All fucking oranges.  Some malt complexities- okay, I lied.  All fucking caramel and orange.  
Taste is orange, some bitterness, well, a lot of bitterness, but creamy and smooth. 
Finish lingers like nobodies business.
Awesome.

500ml bottle. I love all the warnings on the label to NOT age this beer! Bottled on 070908. Poured a medium and slightly hazy golden color with a large sized white head. Aromas of pine, citrus, grassy, floral green hoppiness, with some toastiness. Tastes of citrus, pine, a little earthy, with very light caramel in the background.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear orange body with small white head.  Aroma of citrus, pine, grass, herbs, and earthiness.   Flavor of citrusy hops and caramel malt with a dry, bitter finish.  A tasty IPA.

Pours a fairly clear gold orange, with a thick, foamy white head.  Smells of fresh, crisp, juicy citric hops, with some subtle grapefruit adding some balance.  The flavor is smooth and crisp as well, with a nice balanced hop presence, although pretty strong for a regular IPA.  Pretty sharp hop bitterness in the finish and lingering aftertaste, with traces of that grapefruit citrus showing up as well.  Nicely done IPA, which is no surprise coming from these guys.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2008 Sample at OBriens in San Diego. Pours a deep bronze color with a medium thin downy white head that diminishes slowly. Rings of lacing on the glass. Pine and lemony citrus aroma. Medium-bodied and moderately bitter with pine, hops and citrus flavors in varying degrees. Some malt is present as well. The finish is hoppy and resinous with a lingering bitterness afterward. Not much to complain about here.

Bottle from Healthy Spirits in SF. Light amber color with a minimal white head. Citrus and pine aromas over somewhat roasted malt. Medium body with very mild carbonation. Flavor is mild malt and primarily citrus hop. Some light stone fruit seems present. Finish is very clean. So tasty it could be a DIPA, but rather than run of the mill it’s an exceptional IPA. I’m enjoying it.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2008 Thanks to Bman1113VR for the bottle!  Bottled 7/9/08.  Slightly hazy gold pour, fluffy white head and excellent lace.   Citrusy/ piney hop aroma.  Clean, chewy, and resinous mouth-feel.  Light bodied and quite refreshing.  Loads of citrusy hop flavor.  Bitter & dry finish.  Lingering flavor of nectarine.

Bottle, thanks Dr. Bill!  Light golden color with a wispy foam that lasts well.  Very nice nose, which is dominated by very bright woodsy hops, with other light notes of resin and lemon from the hops.  Flavor hoppiness and bitterness is very bold and impressive, and lingers in the finish very well.  The hops are raw, pure, well utilized and again, they linger well after the swallow.  Flavor hops are similar to the nose and can best be described as very woodsy.  A minor critique, it doesn’t have a lot of body, but the finish makes up for it.  Overall, really nice IPA.

Bottle, barely two weeks old.  Pours a very lightly hazy orange-amber color.  A frothy, off-white head settles to a thin, asymmetrical, bubbly layer.  Sticky lacing coats the glass in an organic honeycomb pattern.  The aroma shows fresh, juicy orange and grapefruit, hints of apricot, bitter, grassy hops, and a lightly toasty toffee malt background.  The flavor packages those same elements into an ultra-clean, refreshing package.  The citrus asserts itself a bit more, with big-time grapefruit and a touch of lemongrass shutting out any hints of apricot that the nose foreshadowed.  The toffee malt imparts just the right amount of sweetness, without getting in the way of the hops or muddling things up.  Medium-full bodied and moderately carbonated, the finish is on the dry side and very clean, lending supreme drinkability.  This is definitely an "everyday" cousin of Pliny the Elder.  Another damn fine beer from Russian River.

Bought a few bottles from More Beer in Concord, CA. Poured orange-gold with white head. Aroma is pure hops, slight citrus notes, smells like true bitter IPA. Flavor is hops with slight malt up front. Tastes of hop flowers, very little bitterness except at the back of the tongue. A great IPA that is easily drinkable and packed with beautiful hop flavors.

On tap at Horse Brass--Poured a West Coast IPA body light orange-golden with a frothy blanketing white head.  Big citrus floral hoppy aroma.  Similar to Pliny but with less of a malt spine.  Grapefruit and pine notes rule this beer.  Very smooth for how unbalanced it is.  Yum!

Bottle. Sampled 7/28, bottled 7/23. 5 days in the bottle, ballin. Lots of fresh, grassy, floral, spicy, bitter hops and enough malt to give it some body. Excellently unbalanced. Medium body, balanced carbonation. Dry finish, very drinkable. Great IPA.

Draft at Pizza Port Carlsbad and tasted out of the bottle as well.  Bottle version was better.  Nice citrusy hops provided for a nice aroma and flavor but there was something there that turned me off that i couldnt put my finger on...

On draft in beautiful San Diego.  Golden-orange pour with a full, white head.  beautiful, big hop aroma with citrus and pine in the foretaste.  Finishes sweeter than the Russian River IPA.   Very good beer!

Bottle from South Bay Drugs and Liquor. Liquid was a pure gold in color and showed equilibrium of sediment while a sticky layer of foam was the head. The aroma is a big and bold serving of hops that smelled fresh and green which was welcomed by my nose. The flavor was heavily hopped that came to me as no surprise but also allowed some room for malt and metallic aftertaste.

16 oz. bottle.  Pours clear with a medium orange tint and is crystal clear.  Smell is incredibly fresh with bright orange citrus notes and light piney bitterness as well.  Taste is very crisp overall, with a hoppy bitterness and grapefruit character.  Not overly flavorful and didn’t blow me away exactly, but an extremely solid and well made beer.  Tastes extremely similar to Pliny the Elder, to me, but with less malt backing and body, and with equal bitterness and flavors.

I can tell this is going to be good. It looks exactly the way an IPA should. A perfect slightly cloudy blond with a long lasting white head. Aroma is wonderful. Very fruity. Grapefruit mostly, some pine and just a touch of hops. Flavor is more bitter. The hops and pine come through more here. There is some lemon flavor, and the grapefruit is still there too. Very warm aftertaste. Some ginger and nutmeg with fresh hops. Medium bodied, almost full bodied. If I were rating for style, I would say that this is more like an Imperial IPA, but I’m not. I find this to be quite pleasant all around. Not complex, but quite flavorful. Just the way I like it.

500ml, bottled 070908, with thanks to AgentSteve for the hookup!  Pours a hazy golden with orange highlights and a two finger white head, good lacing.  Aroma is pine, grapefruit, apricot and light floral.  Flavor is a bigger hit of hops bitterness for a standard IPA, with more pine, citrus, and some earthy resin; the bitterness lingers quite a while on the palate.  A very nice and enjoyable IPA that is not shy about bringing the hops.  Thanks again Steve!

Bottle. A very solid single IPA. Pours a clear burnt gold with a fluffy white head. Aroma is very fresh piney and grapefruit hops, kumquats too. Really good tasting IPA with earthy and grapefruit elements. Light carbonation, somewhat syrupy mouthfeel. Great litttle bottle of beer.

On tap at RR.  Poured amber witha big white head.  Aroma of hops, pine and citrus.  Taste is of piney resinous hops, with a little citrus and caramel.  Quite a bit different from their other IPA/IIPA’s.  Finishes bitter.  Mouth is a moderately bodied.  A nice IPA.
tap at the brewery.  Nice gold color. Aroma is all piney hops.  Hop is no overpowering and malty undercurrent matches it nicely.  This is how a hoppy beer should taste.  I could drink this all day.

Tap @ O’Brien’s.  Pours clear gold with a nice white head.  Floral hop aroma, some pine, and just a little grapefruit.  Sharp hop taste up front, resin flavors dominating the citrus, with a caramel back.  Overall, a great IPA with strong hop flavors but with a light body.

Poured on tap at Marin Brew Breast Fest a blond-amber with large white head.  Huge aroma of floral hops, pine and citrus.  Flavor is dry with pine resin, gratefruit, and the lingering bitterness of the floral hop resin.  The floral and bitter hops overwhelm most of the malt mouthfeel and have little to no sweetness to balance.  This was a good IPA but I’ll stick with the Pliney’s if I have a choice.

On tap @ Tornado San Diego.  Pours a clear golden yellow with a 2 finger white head.  Bursting with floral and citrus hop aromas.  A perfect balance between malt and hops on this one....well......maybe a bit heavier on the hops.....lol.
Draft at the brewpub.  Blond / light amber pour.  Aroma is pine hops mostly, resinous.  Flavor is the same, some sweeter malt underneath, pine / earthy bittering finish.

Growler courtesy tpd975. Pours a clear deep golden with a one finger white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of citrus and a touch of pine hops with notes of sweet malt and a hint of caramel. Taste is the same as aroma with the pine being more prominent. Medium mouthfeel with a moderate to strong amount of bitterness. Another tasty brew from Russian River.

Another winner by Russian River!!!  Sampled on tap @ Hollingshead.  Bronze in color with a hint of sunset.  Smaller cotton head that leaves a bit of spotty lacing.  All that a IPA should be...bitter but not overly so.  Aroma and flavor of grapefruit rind, orange peel, and tropical fruit.  Ponderosa pine notes also come through in the finish.  Cant wait till they bottle this.
I had this next to pliny the elder.  It was very similar but much more refreshing and drinkable.  I appreciate the pine flavour being toned down from their DIPA example.  Very well done.

On tap at OBrines.  Aroma was a bit disappointing; not bad, but not great.  Citrus and grapefruit.  Flavor was very hoppy for the style; not the best hop flavor, but really good.  Color was a clear gold/yellow with not much head.  Managed to be balanced, despite the strong hop presence.  REally good for style.
On tap at Hollingshead. Clear gold with white head. Aroma of citrus peel, resin and hops. Flavor is pine, citrus and spice. Ends with a bit of bitterness. Well balanced. Would buy again.

Had to give this one a slightly lower score than Pliny the Elder, as that beer edges out this one.  Other than that, this is a perfect beer.  Russian River brew pub is stunning, having to decide between R.R. IPA, Blind Pig and Pliny is a crazy tough choice (presuming you are ignoring the amazing Belgians).
On tap at brewery. Pours a clear golden amber. 1/4 inch head that dissipated pretty quickly. Strong fresh hop aroma of pine and citrus. Very drinkable IPA
On tap at the pub. Clear gold with little head. Nose of citrus peel and hops. Flavor is bitter pine and hop resin with some floral aromas and spice as well. Ending in a bit more bitter than expected.

On tap @ Toronado. Pours a clear golden with a small white head. Very light sweetness with a moderate bitterness. Heavy hopsaromas of flowers, grepefruit and spruce and a hint of plant sap. Light to medium bodied. Average carbonation. Bitter finish.

A really decent beer, but really hard to rate this in their sampler next to the two Pliney beers.  Its very well balanced between hoppy and malty, syrupy, sweet, and bitter.  The aroma and everything about this is well crafted.  RR is quite the brewery!
Tap @ Dr. Bills. Thick white head on top of a deep amber body. Lots of lace. Lovely spruce and pine aromas. Solid body. Grassy bitterness leaves a lovely lingering finish. Gorgeous IPA.

(Hand-bottled, thanks Esa K.) Clear amber with a small, bright white head. Very crisp, lemony-piney aroma. Crisply aromatic-hoppy, pine-resiny flavor with some exotic fruitiness. Very dry and bitter mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Nicely drinkable for the amount of hops. Like the first batches of Severin, but without the cat-pee, and even drier and more bitter.

A- This beer had a huge 2 finger head right off the tap which seemed to get bigger as I drank it and left tons of lacing. It was a light orange color.

S- Smell was of piney hops with a small amount of a citrus kick. The hops smelled like the amazing scent of adding hops to a wort boil, almost no other IPA that ive had has recreated this smell

T- Taste was very hoppy for a standard ipa, with blended citrus notes. Sweet pine taste seemed to dominate followed by a rich grainy fullness.

M- Very crisp and carbonated but not as viscous as some of RRs other offerings. Went down very smooth.

D- This beer was very drinkable. It did seem to me that it was stronger than 6 percent but none the less it went down fairly easy.
UPDATED: JUL 8, 2008 If this one suffers at all its simply from being tasted side by side with Pliny the Elder and RR IPA, both of which I really love.  This is tough competition at this brewery!
Drank it on tap at the brewery.  Pours light golden with a nice piney aroma.  Light bodied, and very easy to drink

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2008 Sampling from Mike. Thanks again bro! Big citrus hop aroma. Orange gold color with a nice head and sticky lacing. Hops over power much everything in this one. A touch of caramel malt lends "balance", but this is how I like it. The hop resins lingering in this one forever. Freaking awesome. Best tasting ever.
Pours a pale orange color with white head.  Aroma is malty with lots of citrus hops.  Flavor is caramel and a bitter citrus hop finish.  Great flavorful IPA I could drink this everyday.

On-tap at Toronado 2/17/08. Pours a honey yellow color, frothy white head, some lace. Smells grassy hoppy, I didnt think it was all that complex but I could be wrong. Tastes grassy, hoppy bitter. A bit resiny. Mouthfeel is thin, carbonation is somewhat subdued. Not as good as the Plinys but a good consolation prize.

First beer in Toronado this trip, clean crisp malts great hops, and that juicyness that I have come to love from this beer, and the plineys.  Easier than the Plineys, but still bag loads of hops, simcoe?    Would this get lost in the UK, Id love to throw this blind into a tasting...

On tap at Toronado. 

Light amber color, tan head. Really sticky lace, looks appetizing. 

Smells very juicy. Pine and citrus and fruit, great layering of different hops. 

Full flavored, a ton of hoppiness. Succulent pine and citrus, grapefruit, spice, pale malt, nice bitterness level. 

Smooth, good carbonation, extremely drinkable. Russian River really cant do any wrong.

From growler shipped to me (6 days old when opened):  Golden in color with a touch of amber.  This still poured a great 3/4" head that dissipated slowly.  The nose was filled with grapefruit, Rouquefort cheese and a touch of anise.  In the mouth it had medium density, a smooth texture and was wonderfully balanced.  The hops are very well balanced by some malt that leads to a beer with a bitterness/dryness but also a touch of sweetness.  The malt is more noticable than the "Pliny the Elder" and keeps this beer a touch sweeter.  Overall, this is a really well made beer with terrific balance that is easy to drink.

On tap at Russian River - Golden-amber color with a light head.  Aroma is dominated by sweet citrus hoppiness.  Flavor is a nice citrus hop, sweet mix of goodness.  Some light and sweet malts here, but mostly just solid IPA.  The way all IPAs should be - perfect malt/hop balance for a regular IPA.  Vinny is a genious with this stuff!

Tap: Clear gold with a sticky lacing.  Almost a molding hop compost pile arom, but not bad.  Interesting, distinctive.  Great blunt bitter baseball bat to the tongue with a slightly tinny aftertaste.  Yummy, quite enjoyable.

Served on draft at the Toronado. Light amber body with a thin white head. The aroma is all wicked strong grapefruit. The flavor is much the same; big grapefruit flavor with backing malt and good bitterness. Medium body that seems more alcoholic than it is. All around a classic big west coast IPA.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2009 GABF 2006-Huge C hop aroma, almost chewy. Piney, citrusy, bitter flavor. Yum.
 
500ml bottle, dated 09/30/08. Aroma of honey, pine, citrus (tangerine), and resin. Smells great. Golden orange color with a slight haze and a wispy head. Steady carbonation. Lots of aggressive, resiny, piney hops right off the bat give way to more of the same along with  honey and citrus. Hops sting into the finish. A west coast IPA, to be certain, but I long for some of the gentle hops flavor of its lightly big brother PtE.

Pours a clear burned orange with lively carbonation and big creamy head that dies into sheets of lacing. Holy moley the smell! Smells like a bag of the world finest reefer! Or big juicy piney hops! Taste is nothing but the finest hops, so juicy, so piney, so delicious! A little malty balance to make this a masterpiece. Medium in the mouth with good carbonation and an awesome bitter hop finish. Sessionable? I wish I had this on demand to session. Honestly the best IPA Ive had to date

Consumed on tap at Toranado. It poured clear deep gold with bright white head and decent lacing. The aroma is medium in strength consisting of grapefruit citrus hops. It is pretty fruity in its citrusiness. The flavor is solid grapefruit hops beginning with both bitterness and mild sweet grapefruit hop flavors. It then becomes more and more bitter into the finish.

Tap. Light caramel note for the malt, heavy note of orange/grapefruit and pine for the hops, and a light smell of dough and musty for the yeast with apple and wood in the background. Head is small, creamy, white, has excellent lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is a clear amber. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately bitter, then the very long finish is moderately acidic and heavily bitter. Palate is medium, oily/creamy and has a carbonation between soft and lively. It finishes astringent and very dry and crisp. This a fantastic IPA.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2008 Date: 10/13/2007
Mode: Draft
Source: Brewfest, GABF

Appearance: clear dark gold, frothy dirty white head, 
Aroma: sweet citrus aroma, 
Flavor: big sweet malt flavor, lots of balancing citrus hops, light bitter finish provide perfect balance, 
-------- />
Date: 09/16/2008
Mode: bottle
Words: south bay

Appearance: hazy gold, wispy off white head, 
Aroma: sweet crystal malt aroma with tons of citrus hops, 
Body: creamy body, 
Flavor: sweet malt flavor, lots of hop flavor and bitterness, long bitter finish, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.7/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **4

Draft.  Bad ass stuff.  It smells like a cathedral of hops - noble, genteel even, but very, very serious.  A weighty IPA, it hides all of its astringency with a blast of hops upon hops uopn hops.  Grassy, lush, citrusy, with a dark malt backing - like a canvas for great art. This beer is really an achievement.
GABF 2007.  The best IPA I sampled @ the fest.  Strong hop character, much like a IIPA w/out the malt to back it up.  Just pure hops.  Momma like.
Another delicious beer from Russian River. These guys know what the hell they are doing. Big citrus nose and lots of hops in the flavor. Smooooooth bitterness.
Great IPA with citrus nose.  Some orange and grapefruit notes in the mouthfeel.  Very crisp and dry, would make a great session beer.

Pint draft at the brewery. This is an excellent IPA. I agree with Taverner that its largely a toned down version of Pliny the Elder (double IPA). Having talked to Vinnie Cilurzo (head brewer), he confirmed the recipes are similar.  The citrusy and piney hops are enjoyable throughout the drinking but more complex than a simple Cascade hop bomb.  Very good job!

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2008 Like a toned down "Pliny the Elder," this beer is a good, piney, IPA. The hops hit you right off and sustain. ON SECOND ANALYSIS: Had this on tap at RR with a clean palate - OMG this stuff is good! Has that dank flavor the best IPAs do!

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2008 On tap at Lucky Baldwin’s IPA Festival ’07.  Clear light orange-gold color with a fine white head.  Sweet resinous hops in the aroma with a large fruit element as well--grapefruit, kumquat, cannabis.  The flavor is clean with a "darker" malt profile and leafy herbaceous hops characteristics.  The body is a bit thicker than their regular IPA with heavier bitterness as well.  It is very well balanced nonetheless and leaves with a long, pleasant finish.

On Tap at the BP
Clear light yellow/orange with a full creamy white head tha lasts leaving dense thin lacing.  Citrusy hops on the nose and a nice light but quite hoppy flavor.  Surprised to see so many (72) IBUus listed for it on the board.
Bright abd lively IPA that doesnt feel that big.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2008 On draft at Toronado in San Francisco & bottled release. The one thing I can definitely recall about this brew is PINE. Intense floral aroma off the the  head of sap, resin, pine needles and a slice of fresh cut grapefruit. Not too heavy on the palate, but rather crisp and refreshing from the good level of carbonation. Great dose of bitterness; this is an extremely green-tasting beer, with a sweet malty backbone. Excellent balance, definitely a good example of a superb West Coast IPA / session beer.
Tasted at Stone XI Party.  Clear deep golden amber with no head.  Sweet grapefruit and pine aroma.  Nice tangy citrus, lemon, pragefruit, orange and pine with a bitterness and dry finish.

On tap from Stone 11th party. Nice day to finally sample my first BP. Nice fluffy head on golden hues. Citrus floral aromas. Not overpowering bitterness but nicely balanced with some sweet malt. Perfect IPA for a warm SAn Diego afternoon as I am sure it was intended. Cant wait till it is bottled.

Thanks you Taliskar for the latest growler, which by itself is a work of art replicating a Russian Rivern bottle. Big foamy head on dark grapefruit body. Floral hops, very pleasant aroma. AFter 7 days, we drunk this hardly changed from room temperature and very much liked its smoothness and taste.
UPDATED: AUG 24, 2008 re/rate. On tap @ the brewery. Nice hoppiness to it with a good balance of malt. Quite clean and crisp.

Draft at the brewpub. Pours crystal clear medium amber with a thick, slightly moussy whitish head. Humongous resin and pine nose right from the drop. Nice light/medium body with firm carb thats actually a bit raw. Huge caustic resin and pine notes scour the tongue all the way across, and leave a deep bitter resin cling behind. The raw carb exacerbates the harshness of the chosen hops. Certainly not the bitterest beer Ive had, but the light body, harsh carb, and single-mindedly resiny/piney notes of the hops make it quite a tour de force. As refreshing as a hard slap in the face from a beautiful woman.

Sampled at Russian River in mid-June 2007. Clear golden, almost light copper with a white head. Sharp, citrusy/centennial hop nose - very nice. Flavor has notes of pale malt, grapefruit, cascade/centennial hops, and a  light hint of caramel. Has a proper level of bitterness for an American IPA but not too crazy. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Quite enjoyable.

Draught, Russian River.

Body is medium to dark yellow.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), moderately to heavily hoppy (grapefruit, resin).

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately to heavily bitter.

Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation.

Im not particularly fond of Vinnies hop bombs like this and the Plinies, but those who love it west coast styled will undoubtedly find this exciting.

draft @ lucky baldwins IPA fest - right up there as one of my favorite IPAs of the moment. loads of pine and citrusy hops up front...solid malt background but its way way way in the background. super smooth drinking.
Rich yellow, clinging head.  The West Coast IPA--low malts, to be sure (I would prefer more) but beautifully executed as an example of the style.

Had a pint of this at the brewpub while I picking up a Growler of Pliny .  Aroma of citrus hops and a nice dark golden color and a small pub style head and thin lacing.  Mouthfeel was delightful and very crisp and refreshing. Flavor was of various citrus and fruits such as orange and apricot.  Good long bitter and dry finish.  A very good IPA, ranking up there with the very best.   A hopheads delight.

Draught at the brewery. Beer is hazy, medium oxidized-gold colored with a small-to-average sized, white, frothy-creamy, diminishing clingy head.

The aroma is malty with moderate notes of toasted grain, caramel; Hoppy with heavy notes of resin/pine, apricot, grapefruit oil, moderate orange and lemon zest; Yeasty with a trace of dough; Light miscellaneous note of tropical fruit.

The flavor is moderately-to-heavily sweet, moderate-to-heavily acidic, moderately-to-heavily bitter with a long, moderately bitter, light-to-moderately sweet, trace acidic finish. Grippy, but not hostile.

The body is medium, the texture is watery-to-velvety and the carbonation is lively.
Goldenish coloured with a white head. Grapefruit hops aromas. Dry and bitter with pine and grapefruit hops in the taste. A bit of maltyness in there.
(on tap @ toronado)yellow body with a small white head.lots of pine type hops in the aroma and flavor.pretty tasty,although nothing really special about it.

Well hot damn, I hadnt heard anything about this and was remarkably surprised when having it.  Draught pint at PP Carlsbad on 3/24/07 while waiting in line for pizza.Very nice pale-golden body has a hint of straw and a medium amount of white head.  Slight chill-haze, modestly carbonated.Damn!  Thats a dry and very nicely dry-hopped aroma.  No malt to speak of, or rather, none that gets in the way of the hops.  Clear and brisk lemon-lime, with even a hint of spiciness, followed by dry, but not overly acidic grapefruit.  Some light pale malts provide a hint of sweetness, for balance, akin to powdered sugar atop nectarines (mixing with the hops), with a pinch of some biscuit notes.  The rest is just pure aromatic, dry-hopped heaven, very fresh, crisp and in your face, though not overdone on acidity.  Light herbal notes, with stronger wintergreen and dry melon.  Phew, thats nice!Perfectly attenuated, with malt left for a smooth texture, but only minimal, lightly crisp, grainy flavors.  More nectarine, lychee, lemon, grapefruit and soft pine on the finish.  Tight carbonation for a draught beer, leads to an almost creamy mouthfeel which further helps balance the very dry nature of the beer.  Dry, yellow fruitiness lingers on, with melon and lychee.  Just delicious stuff and incredibly drinkable for its dryness.  No alcohol or flaws, of course.  Great restraint on the bitterness/acidity.

Great session beer!!  Had this one back on my 21st birthday.  Doesnt come around often, but a nice beer to get someone used to these big ass west coast ipas. no doubt.  very well balanced, a great beer all-around.

(On tap - Toronado) Clear, golden with an off-white head. Very fresh, citric aroma. Medium body with sweet, pale malts and then the most wonderful fruity accents. The finish is dry and bitter. A brilliant IPA. 250307

On tap at the Toronado. What more can you say? Its the grandpappy of IPAs. Pours a nice, somewhat hazy orange with a surprisingly light, thin head. Big piney and grapefruit hops waft from the glass, so you know what youre in for. The hops take over your first sip and really show no mercy to the malt in the background. A bit unbalanced. This is straight up, O.G. West Coast IPA style. Lots of grapefruit and pinestraw. Good body with a clean, crisp and pretty dry finish. IPAs have come a long way since Vinnie first brewed this in the mid-90s, but this still holds court with the better ones of today. Cheers to a legend.

Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear golden color. Head was thin, white, and left a bit of lace on the glass. Aroma and flavor were dominated by grapefruit and pine resin. The beers delicate malty sweetness is overwhelmed by its ample hop bitterness. Tasty.

On tap.  Lots of piney hops in the nose with a light citrus note.  Amber with minimal off white head.  Nice malt balance with a slight sugar tinge that balances the bitter hops nicely.  Well executed IPA.

Draught @ the brewery. Smells like roasted malts and pine. Tastes like the hop concentration was spot on compared to the RRs IPA. Could detect a grapfruit and caramel taste. Although a little on the watery side, still pretty impressive.

Huge aromatic nose of hops, deep copper-amber color, low head. Sweet soft malt body gets quickly overpowered by a huge West Coast hop flavor. Not harsh, though, and well-balanced. Big bitter to satisfy any hop head.

A hazy orange beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is super delicious witth hoppy notes of grass and pine needles. The flavor is very much in balance between the sweetness and the bitternes with notes of malt, and lots of hops, giving it notes of grass, pine needles and grapefruit. Thanks a bunch to Kasper at Nørrebro Bryghus for serving this at my birthday party, hand bottle by Vinny - what a treat!

on tap at the Toronado on 1/15/07.  clear golden color, creamy off-white head.  aroma is pine resin, sweat, and urine.  flavor is very strong pine hops - resiny.  bitterness is strong, but not an attack somehow - the finish fades.

1/2 pint at RR - Aroma is dank earthy fresh hops, citrus and malt.  Pours semi-tranparent  yellow with little head and lacing.  Flavor is a match to the aroma.  Palate is incredibly smooth for the amount of hoppiness.  Very tasty if not a tad unbalanced.  I love the dank hops.

Had on tap at Lucky Baldwins in late June 2006: Pours a clear copper bronze with a frothy and well-lacing white head.  Rich, fresh, piny grapefruity hoppy aroma has a light caramel malty balance.  Body starts with a mild toasty caramel sweetness and big fresh citrus hoppy flavor drying some toward a crisp bitter finish.  An enjoyable hoppy IPA.
Draft, at Monks cafe RR dinner. The only non "-tion" beer on the menu. Amber color, with a strong hop aroma. Flavor was all hops, with a dry finish.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2007 Served on tap at Toronado, sf. I hate tasting in a bar; much prefer having a new beer in quiet setting, especially good beers like this. That said, its easy to tell that this is a solid IPA. Would love to compare it with others at home.

On tap at OBriens 1/19/07.  Usually drinking a triple then a double IPA then a regular IPA might cause problems.  Not true with Blind Pig.  Poured clear dark yellow with no head.  There was a very minimal hoppy aroma.  This brew has a huge front heavy hoppy taste, that has an incrediblly large bitter punch.  The supreme bitterness may be partially obliterating my taste buds.  This brew for 6% is quite difficult to drink quickly.

(on-tap @ Toronado) pint is a very pretty glowing orange/amber, with a sticky white head that retains well and leaves good lace. nose is wonderful, like sugar-dipped lemon slices, maybe chewed in a bed of pine needles. flavor is fuller and richer than Vinnies normal IPAs - a lot of chewy malts up-front with tons of citric hop flavor and a good whack of bitterness in the back. great burps. great beer, but perhaps a bit heavy for multiple pints.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2007 Pours a fairly clear light amber with a loose white head. Aroma is huge pine and grapefruit. Body is med. light with med. CO2. The flavors are very hop forward, very piney, very heavily grapefruit, (Chinook and cascade?) and the malts are barely even there. Just enough to lightly balance the hop flavor but not enough to balance the bitterness which is intense, maybe bordering on astringent. Extremely dry finish. This is one hell of an IPA and deserving of all the hype it has gotten. Just beautiful.

Draught Toronado Pub. Beautiful perfumy hop aroma. Hazy dark gold. Lighter in color than the Moonlight Bombay by Boat IPA I had previously. Artful lace. Excellent lace. Very good bitterness. Best IPA of the night. Outstanding.

GABF 2006:  Clear amber color with an off-white head.  Nice strong piney, resiny, grapefruit  and earthy hop aroma that carries over to the flavor.  The hops almost hide the caramel maltiness.  Solid IPA.

GABF 2006. Amber body with a small white head. Aroma is big piney hops and some grapefruit and orange peel. Taste is fruity and bitter with more evergreen, caramel, sweet malts and citrus peels. Body is medium-full with a resinous, oily feel. Finishes with more piney and citric hops, caramel and sweet creamy malts. Nice IPA, but would you expect anything less from Russian River?
Pour is clear golden with a thin off white head...piney resinous nose...aggressively bitter flavor...nice malty undertones of biscuits and bread, but strongly citrus bitter...

Draft... GABF 06... Mostly clear golden ale with a small, frothy, off-white head. Earthy, piney, woodsy aroma. The flavor leans just a tad on the bitter side of balance; a pinch of salt. Medium-bodied and astringent with  medium carbonation. Lengthy, medium bitter, dry finish.

Somewhat vegetative hop character. This a 90s blast from the harsh hop past. Lots of pine and grapefruit in the nose. Mild malt body that is dominated by the very vegetative bitterness. Astringent finish that makes me grab  a Pliny.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2007 Draft.  Very pale copper color with a white head.  Strong grapefruit and piney aromas.  Flavor is bitter and very hop forward with grapefruit, pine, grass and fruit notes. Very crisp.  Dry, bitter finish.  A true west coast IPA.

GABF 2006.  The beer pours to a golden body with a white head.  The aroma is awesome.  Extreme hopping.  Fruity peaches, nectarines, pineapple, simcoe-esque hops.  The flavor is malty and hoppy and nicely bitter.  Decent bitter resiny palate.

golden yellow color white well laced head.  very fresh citrus hop aroma orange peel and carmel, palate is dry well coated and oily.  Flavor of dry pine resins some light carmels, is quite bitter.  Reminds me of the pliney.

GABF 2006.  Clear straw color, light white head.  Aroma - nice hops, but malt is evident.  Really nice balance of hops and malt flavor.  A little light in hop bitterness.  Overall, easy drinking, good malt and hops.  Bitter in the finish, but just a little light.
gabf 06.  light orange.  big fresh citrus  hop aroma.  Taste is nice and bitter and citrusy up front with notes of caramel malt.  Good firm bitter finish.

Enjoyed this one on draught,  this past July, when I paid Russian RIver Brewing a visit.They had four IPAs on draught the day I visited,  and of the four, Blind Pig was my favorite. This beer is a classic example of AIPA just bursting with hop aromas, flavors, and bitterness. This beer pours to a beautiful, slightly hazy, orange color, with a creamy white head, and a moderate carbonation. The nose on this beer is just so zesty, and fragrant. It explodes with big lemon peel/citus and piney hop aromas. The palate is firm, with some good sweet/pale malt, paired with lots of really good, tangy, lemon/citrus hop flavor. Blind Pig finishes with more good sweet malt and tangy hops up front, then ends with a big, mouth puckering bust of lemon/citrus hop bittereness that lingers. Outstanding AIPA, one with such character, yet so drinakble. A fantastic pint at the brewpub, one to sip and savor, and to enjoy with the delicious brick oven pizzas served at Russian River. Well worth a trip out to Santa Rosa, CA to try.

Tap @ Obreins san diego: Pours copper color small fading head. Taste  mostly malts with very little hop showing. Finish has somewhat of burnt aftertaste which allow the beer to linger around the bridge of the mouth much too long for my taste. also unable to pull much hops from aroma. Passable brew for me!

tap at the brewpub - Things really started looking up for my Russian River sampler when I got to the Blind Pig.  An assertive citrus hops aroma starts it off.  The flavor strikes a good balance with lots of malt creeping up on the moderately intense hops.  It has a fairly mild finish for an IPA, but it still lingers for awhile.
On tap at Russian River Brewpub: Nice orange color with a small head. Intense fresh hoos nose. Lemony edge, medium intense, medium lasting hoppy taste. Nice one. Thanks Natalie!

On tap at Toronado. This copper ale poured with a thin white head. There is a full hoppy flavor, a lemon finish and a carbonated mouthfeel.  The hops are tasty and not overdone. Another fine brew from Russian River.

<!-- !-- i -- -->Draught at Lucky Baldwins, Pasadena<!-- !-- /i -- --><!-- !-- br -- -->Had this beer during the IPA festival. Slightly hazy, golden orange color. Thick, dense, rocky, lasting head. Huge bouquet of hops, smells like mostly Amarillo. Great hop flavor with only a slight acrid tang. Very smooth palate and finish.

On tap @ Russian River poured a clear copper with a small diminishing white head. Aromas of orange, lemon, pine and carmel. Palate was light bodied and dry. Flavors of carmel, pine and grapefruit with a lingering bitter finish.
On tap poured clear gold with nice white head and nice lacing. Awesome hop aroma with little malt presents. Bittering hops hit right away with a dry hoppy finish. Has to be one of the top IPAs.

On tap 6/12 @ The Liars Club: Pours a clear golden color with an off-white head that diminishes quickly leaving nice lacing. Hoppy aroma has hints of grapefruit, floral and pine. Flavor is all about the hops leaving a grapefruit bitter finish. The hops are not overpowering making this enjoyable to drink. A must try for any Hop Heads!

On tap at Hollingshead Deli.  Pours a transparent golden color with a finger of soapy white head.  Aroma is deliciously rich with hops.  Some sweet ruby red grapefruit citrus tones are complimented by a light peach fruitiness and sweetened with a squeeze of honey.  Light, crisp refreshing mouthfeel with a sparkling burst of thirst quenching carbonation on the tongue.  Loads of grapefruit hops flood the palate instantly, but are soon backed evenly by a mildly sweet pineapple glaze.  Forget the bretts for the time being - an overall delicious and another great example of Russian Rivers mastery of the hops.

On tap at OBriens & Liars Club.  Pours a clear golden color with a nice looking medium sized head and just a little bit of lacing.  Aroma is HOPS and more hops... so yummy smelling.  Pine and the slightest floral hint hit the nose as well.  Flavor is all hops with hints of grapefruit and floral tones underneath.  This is an absolutely fantastic beer and I love the fact that its on regularly at two of my favorite beer joints!  Another great RR beer (not surprising).

UPDATED: APR 29, 2008 Tap at Najas in Redondo Beach. Very good, thick and rich flavor. I would certainly order again.  Worth having a few more. I think every Russian River beer I have sampled has been exceptional. 

Re rated: 4/27/08. to a 4.0  Again, I had this at Najas, they had it listed as Blind Pig Double IPA, which I questioned. I had a Pliny and then Blind Pig, if Pliny is a double (which it is) BP is a single. Its delicious, one of the finest single IPA I have encountered.
Bottle. Golden colour with a big white head. Grapefruit, hop aroma and a dry grapefruit, floral hop taste. Medium to full body with a very dry finish.

Bottle.
Clear golden coloured with a white head.
Aroma of hops and grape fruits with notes of pine needles.
Flavour of fruits, hops and grape fruits with notes of pine needles.

This beer was on tap at Liars Club.  The aroma had light pine, malts, and fruit notes with an earthy texture and oranges, and grapefruits.  The beer poured an orangish brown color with yellow hues, no head and almost no lacing.  The flavor had citrus like grapefruits, oranges, then pine with an earthy note and light malt and caramel.  The mouthfeel was light and crisp with a good bitterness.

On tap at The Bistro/Hayward - This is simply one outstanding IPA. Russian River doesnt EVER fail to deliver and this IPA is nothing less that expected. Aroma is citrusy and floral. Appearance is a bright, clear orange/light orange in color with a rather small head (this was pouring it out of my pint glass into a proper tulip glass too). Mouthfeel is medium in body, lightly carbonated. Flavor is a near perfect balance between hoppy delight and malty goodness. A ton of orange/citrus/grapefruit combo in the flavor along with the strong malt backbone makes this incredibly balanced. Top notch IPA, and would beat the pants off of some IIPAs.

Tap at OBriens. Had this side by side with their IIPA as well as a few others. Ligher amber body than the IIPA, as well as a less assertive aroma. Still, this didnt mean much. Huge piney citrusy aroma. I really strugged to detect where the hops were from for some reason... no idea. This IPA was different from a lot Ive had from Cali. Still really hoppy and bitter and I thought it was well balanced as well.
Another absolute winner from Russian River.  These folks understand the importance of adding obscene amounts of hops to their beers.  This is no exception.  A well balanced IPA from nose to belly.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2006 Pours a lovely golden color, with a nice fluffy head.  Some pine flavors mixed with a wonderful piney hop taste.  This stuff smells amazing.  If you have ever opened a very fresh bag of Northern California Marijuana, thats what I smell. Amazing stuff. The original IIPA.

Too cool, Im live on [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */Briens rating a pint of Blind Pig:  Lightly hazy golden amber color with a small (bar pour) white head. Sweet pineapple citrus nose. Flavor starts fruity sweet turning grapefruit bitter with a long dry grapefruit rind finish.  Medium bodied, smooth and dry with moderate carbonation.
a little clear. orange yellow colur. aroma of very fresh hops.  citrus aroma too. flavor is of hella hops and watery citrus. very bitter just citrus orange nothin else dog.

On tap at the Toronado. Rich gold in color with a white head. Thick hop aroma. Flowery, but not very citrus-like. Flavor is a different story: Love at first sip! This could be grapefruit juice. Tastes like youre drinking a freakin citrus tree! Fantastic.

Draught at Liars ClubPours a hazy yellow colod with light, thin white head and moderate lacing. The nose is ripe and citrusy with some hops and some tangy grassy malt notes. The flavor is rich with a thick body and some caramel malts. A nice IPA, right around the par of regular IPAs in this area. Double IPA? San Diego IPA? Sorry, time has passed. The finish is creamy, balanced. Nice upfront floral hops. I like.

Pours with an orangish-gold body toped by a medium thick head with good lacing.  Its bitter and hoppy with notes of citrus and pine, and a very slight underlying sweet malt note.  Medium bodied, smooth and a touch dry.  Definately a beer I will be drinking more of.

Having old friends remember the original, I was very excited to finally try the mother of the pliney.  But to my dismay, it didnt hold up, but 10 years ago, this would have been nice.  Pours a clean orange/yellow hue with aromas of pine, and citrus.  Flavors of the same with a nice bitterness.   For being 6%, this does make a nice session brew.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2009 Tap @ Liars Club. Not much notes on this one but I remember it being amazingly fresh & spicey, with a fresh, clean floral, piney hoppiness on the body. Nice fresh malt flavors & grapefruit. It was a medley of flavors that were in no way homoginized together. Very nice, clean tasting medium bodied IPA. 9/6/09 Im upping this 2 points to a 4. Very fresh, clean tasting, quality IPA on tap at RR.

Draft.  Yellow straw color with a small white head.  Citrus, floral hop aroma.  Juicyfruit flavors quickly overcome by a heavy resinous bitterness.  Resin astringency and tinges of pinesol in the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium heavy, rather dry.

On cask at OBriens.  Arrived a deep golden color with a bit of haziness and a moderate sized creamy head.  Bold hop nose along with abundant caramel malts, light vanilla scent and spicy, tangy grapefruit.  Sweet lemon, brash grapefruit supported by a solid caramel malt backbone, clover, grass with more of the grapefruit in the finish.  Medium to full body, gentle, cask carbonation.  I found this one to be smooth and nicely balanced for a big bold IPA.  Quite good overall.
Draft at the Hoppiest Place on Earth. Another IPA that represents the West Coast properly. Bright citrus zest with some cinnamon and some sweet malts. Perfect with spicy food.

[Cask at OBriens] Poured a lightly hazy, copper color with a medium sized, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of citrus fruits, pine resin, floral hops and faint malts as well.  Taste was super, tangerine and other citrus fruits, more pine and a strong grapefruit bitterness.  The IBUs are incredible on this one.

Draft at OBriens.  Awesome Aromas seeping out of this golden orange brew.  Sweet citrus... Orange, Ruby Red Grapefruit.  Light Pineapple.  Flavors were citurs at first with a piney/grassy finish.  Very good.

On tap at hollingshead deli in Orange, CA
This brew has a nice golden color with an outstanding hop aroma. Hoppy up front with a smooth finish. This is a very nice IPA. Id highly recommend it.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2006 On draught at the release party tonight at OBriens here in SD. I guess it has been available elsewhere further north but is now returning to its original home for the first time in a while. Smooth and drinkable, hops tone is mildly fruity. Not a lot of head retention. Somewhat sweet aftertaste which is slightly surprising, but pleasant.
A pretty good IPA, hops dominate of course, but its a very drinkable IPA, could get into trouble with this one by drinking a few too quickly! lol. On tap at Hollingsheads.

A legend in its own time, this beer is hard to find (outside of Santa Rosa, that is).  Good, standard IPA worth sampling again and again.  Big white head.  Clear,  deep gold.  Nice hop aroma.  Great bitterness.  Always a contender for your glass.
On tap at the pub. Medium gold color with a white head. Hoppy aroma with a good bitter flavor.

The third offering in a continuum of Russian River IPAs bottled unofficially by BA RedwoodGeorge from a 5 gallon keg into 22 oz. bombers, the beer came out paler than the two bigger Plinys but had a little more carbonation, and a bigger head.  The aroma was much milder than I had anticipated, with a floral-citric hop smell vaguely reminiscent of Mangos. The taste was citric, sugary, and a little soapy.  Body was light and airy, and the hops faded quickly after each sip.  Like the rest of Russian River IPAs, this was lighter in body than the strength on the label suggested.  Unlike the bigger beers, the lightness of the body had a slightly detrimental effect on the single IPA, where more character is usually better than less.  An easy to drink beer, that left me wishing it was a little less simple.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2006 On tap at the RR brewpub on 2/18/06.  Poured a nice golden color with a finger wide off-white head. Very fresh hoppy aroma some floral, piney notes.  Flavor was very crisp with a good bitter aftertaste.  Not too hoppy, a nice medium bodied IPA.

Draught at the brewpub. Hazy amber. Striking grapefruity nose. Punishing soapy oily hops makes my tastebuds distort. The mouthfeel is fairly soft but the bitterness is relentless and inky. Hardcore IPA.
UPDATED: APR 29, 2014 Slightly hazy light amber, tons of papaya, sugary pale malt.  Dripping with delicious hops, slightly floral, hints of mango, mellow and sweet...this beer lives up to its rep.

This beer is the most drinkable IPA I have ever had, which isnt necessarily a good thing. I would rather it have more flavour and be less drinkable. The IBUs tasted like they were only 35 or so, and the aroma was very lacking for an IPA. There was nearly zero head retention. There was a pretty colour and the ale poured nicely, but it was just too thin of a beer in my opinion. After all, IPAs are not supposed to be session beers. Kinda like the Blind Pig from Temecula brewery years ago

on tap at The Russian River Brewing Company in Santa Rosa, CA. clear marmalade hue. minimal white head. little aroma -some subtle hops. first thing you notice is the viscious (oily) mouthfeel. spicy flavors - grassy hops, carrots, peppers, onions. not impressive.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2005 Tap at the Toronado in SF.
A fine example of an IPA. That is what an IPA should taste like. Extremely hoppy, flowery and has just the right 
bitter aftertaste. Kind of in your face.
Appearance was kind of surprising: very light in color, almost thin looking.
slightly thick palate going down my throat. spicy scented candle aroema. weak head and appearance was lackluster. good flavour though

Tap @ Toronado.  A golden orange color with an off-white head.  A nice fresh hop and floral aroma with a robust wet hop flavor of intense pine.  Some fruity notes at the edges on this otherwise bitter and cleansing palate.

Clear and golden hued,...lush, enormous white head, ...beautiful...a lace-leaver...

Aroma is flat-out piney hops, prickly, sparkly, tingly, tangy, yum...ferociously fresh flavor, pineapple and apricot, lemon, and pine cones...damned fresh...I love it! God, I love it!

Taste it, already...slides on board the palate assuredly and provides the same fresh, vibrant hoppy flavor that blessed the nose. Zips merrily along the tongue, blazing bitterness, but balanced beautifully with zesty flavor. Never, never quits...so easy to drink, and so ample in its hoppy bounty...

Not too anything, this, and just right with all the appropriate ingredients, especially for the hopheads in the house....medium-bodied, with a lightly bitter, fruity finish...holy crud, I could spin every superlative off the top of my head and still feel like Ive missed a few...every IPA Ive tasted from Russian River has been amazing, and this continues that trend...if Vinnie is capable of making a bad one, I dont want to know...

Draught. Golden beer with a thin white head. Grapefruit and tropical fruit aroma. Grapefruit, pine, apricot, tropical fruit hop flavors with some sweet malt backing. Nice bitterness. Finish is a little woody/grainy.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2005 Draught at Brickskeller in DC: The lighting in Brickskeller sucks, so my appearance comments may not be accurate.  I did the best I could in the conditions.  I was lucky to get a pint of this immediately folowing a pint of the IPA, so I could contrast the two.  Moderately hazy golden yellow with a definite bronze-orange tinted body.  Medium white head that is somewhat foamy and does have quite the retention of their plain IPA (though its still nothing to scoff at).  The aroma has more pungent citrus hops than the IPA (which is more pine/grass), but theres still the usual subjects of pine and floral hops with a tiny hint of sweet malt in here that seemes to almost have a bit of dry caramel, almost like munich malt.  The taste has mostly bitter citrus hops at first, with some light pine and floral hops as well, but the more citrus and grapefruit flavors are backed up with a sweeter malt base than the IPA.  Towards the middle one can actually taste just a hint of malt (sweet pale malt, not grainy, with a faint tough of caramel).  Finish is dry (not a surprise from RR), crisp, and has plenty of lingering hops.  Medium bodied, moderate-medium carbonation, dry but showing some signs of malty sweetness.  I really enjoyed the presence, if faint, of the small amount of flavorful malt in this.

This defines IPA for me. Can I just say that over and over and have that be my testament? What more can I really say? A description does not do justice what this does for my tongue and soul.
Sampled by hand carried glass from Natalie as Vinne brewed and Dave Keen and Joe looked on, SaveTheAles pummeled hops and I grinned.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2006 On Tap at 2005 Bistro IPA fest. Light orange gold color. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is orange, citrus and floral hops. A light to medium bodied IPA. Malts are fruity and sweet. Lots of orange and orange peel flavors Hops are grapefruity and citrusy. Medium bitter IPA. Nice balance between the malts and hops. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Cask Version

On cask at OBriens. This IPA pours an orange gold color. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is piney and floral. Malts are fruity and sweet, touch of caramel. Hops are very juicy, floral and piney, without a lot of hop bitterness, There is some hop bitterness in the finish but that is all. Very soft mouthfeel and carbonation. Nicely balanced. The bitterness at the finish builds as you go. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. (9-4-8-4-17)
Pretty good IPA.  Russian River seems to use all piney hops, and this was no differant.  Nice and pleasant, not overly bitter.  Mainly earthy characters with floral and citrus accents.
